channel.title: TGaceAllStories
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from TGaceAllStories, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: I have early Alzheimer’s and my husband has stage 4 kidney disease. We just inherited $50K. How can this help us?
item.description: “We have a 401(k) with $20,000, and $29,000 in a Roth IRA.”

item.title: Philip Morris says black-market cigarettes are a big deal, as sales miss and stock falls
item.description: Shares of Philip Morris, parent of Marlboro cigarettes and Zyn nicotine pouches, dropped after a rare revenue miss, as a growing illicit market for ci...

item.title: ‘I have a degree in economics’: I’m 70, earn $250K a year and have $3.7 million in investments. Is it time to retire?
item.description: “I have a home worth $1.3 million with $900,000 in equity. I have not paid it off as I have a 3% interest rate.”

item.title: Why is Texas Instruments’ stock sliding after earnings? Analysts boil it down to one word.
item.description: Analysts say the tone on the earnings call was “moody” and “appears to have shifted markedly” as executives express more caution.

item.title: Enphase Energy just cast more doubt about its immediate future
item.description: Investors fret about Enphase’s estimates of lower sales in the current quarter.

item.title: Wednesday’s big stock stories: What’s likely to move the market in the next trading session
item.description: The S&P 500 crept slightly higher on Tuesday, just enough to post another record close. Here's what's on CNBC's radar going into Wednesday.

item.title: The buzz around AI 'neoclouds' is growing, but investors should tread carefully
item.description: "Last year, [neoclouds] were very small, but now it's something that you cannot ignore in terms of size," UBS strategist Sundeep Gantori told CNBC.

item.title: Alphabet, Amazon are buys ahead of earnings results, portfolio manager says
item.description: Keith Gangl, portfolio manager at Gradient Investments, joined CNBC's "Power Lunch" to offer his takes on the companies.

item.description: Shares of the electronic broker are up more than 40% this year.

item.title: Brokerages are likely to slash yields on cash. These firms are still offering solid rates
item.description: Brokerage firms aren't waiting for the Federal Reserve to resume cutting rates. They're already lowering yields paid on your idle cash.
